fields.value: Replication Data for: How the News Media Activates Public Expression and Influences National Agendas

dsDescriptionValue.value: We demonstrate that the news media causes Americans to take public stands on issues, join national policy conversations, and express themselves publicly more often than they would otherwise --- all key components of democratic politics. We recruited 48 mostly small media outlets that allowed us to choose groups of outlets to write and publish articles, on subjects we approved, and dates we randomly assigned. We estimate the causal effect on proximal measures, such as website pageviews and Twitter discussion of the articles' specific subjects, and distal ones, such as national Twitter conversation in broad policy areas. Our intervention increased discussion in each broad policy area by $\approx$ 62.7% (relative to a day's volume), accounting for 13,166 additional posts, with similar effects across population subgroups.

publicationCitation.value: Gary King, Benjamin Schneer, and Ariel White. 11/10/2017. “How the news media activate public expression and influence national agendas.” Science, 358, Pp. 776-780. Publisher's Version Copy at http://j.mp/2Awcbw9

files.description: This file summarizes the data used for this study and generates tables to report mean and SD by day of experiment because we are not able to disclose the original data sets.
files.label: deidentify_data.R

files.description: This replication archive includes computer code we used in our analyses, along with full documentation. As discussed in our article, we are unable to disclose potentially identifying information but we have prepared and include here summary tables for each data set reporting cross tabulations of relevant outcome variables (see summary_stats.pdf).
files.label: media_rep_readme.txt

As discussed in our article, we are unable to disclose potentially identifying information but we have prepared and include here summary tables for each data set reporting cross tabulations of relevant outcome variables (see summary_stats.pdf).
